newsitem.title: FINLAND: INSTANT VIEW - Finnish key rate cut.
newsitem.headline: INSTANT VIEW - Finnish key rate cut.

text.p: Following are comments from economists after the Bank of Finland said it was cutting its key tender rate by 10 basis points to 3.00 percent.
Teijo Rantatupa, OKOBANK Treasury Economist:
"It must be some action before something about (a markka link to) ERM leaks, some action before markka gets too strong."
"If they (the Bank of Finland) want a weaker markka they will have to cut the rate more again."
"I think the Bank of Finland (is) preparing the ERM linking and that's their role in this play."
Asked if he felt the cut invited speculation about a markka-ERM link this weekend or soon, he said markets have discounted a link for the markka to Europe's Exchange Rate Mechanism.
"It doesn't matter when it takes place -- the market has discounted it for two to three weeks now. It doesn't matter when it happens."
"The short-term money market has been dictating (a cut) for several days."
"I feel personally that there are a lot of pressures on the markka to strengthen now."
Ari Aaltonen, Postipankki chief analyst:
"This is pleasant ... I've been telling our clients this all day."
"It is the same old story -- that is the markka is too strong."

"It (the markka) is too strong in a tactical sense, since when a link (for the markka to ERM) is negotiated, the starting point will be (the preceding) Friday's level and if that is strong, talks will be more difficult."
He said a link was still possible any weekend this year except perhaps October 20 to 21, when all leading Finnish politicians would be engaged in local and European elections.
"The cut did not increase the likelihood for a link next weekend."
Risto Murto, chief economist at brokerage Selin Finance:
"It looks like the Bank of Finland does not want the markka to appreciate strongly before the ERM-link."
"We are in the waiting room, we are leaving the regime of a completely freely floating exchange rate behind and we are about to link (the markka) to ERM."
"(But) it seems that it is quite difficult to steer the exchange rate trend by marginal interest rate moves."
Asked IF further key rate cuts lied ahead, Murto said: "With this logic, yes. It is not out of the question that the Finnish tender rate could, temporarily, go below the German repo rate."
Juha Lehtonen, analyst at Merita Bank:
"This is an attempt to get the markka to a slightly softer level before its possible linkage to the ERM. It is very difficult to see any other explanation for the cut," he said.
"After this it looks evident that they are taking the markka into the ERM."
"I think it (the markka-ERM link) is more likely to come in the near future than late this year," he said, but declined to name any specific weekend.
"I think there is still room to lower (tender rate). The markka is likely to remain strong, so the Bank of Finland may see room to cut tender rate further."
"I think Germany will not be an absolute floor, but it is obviously difficult to take tender rate much lower than that."
-- Helsinki newsroom +35 80 6805 0247
